ClusteringComparisonHelper¶

ClusteringComparisonHelper.rand_index_visualization(x_df, y_df, clustered_df1, clustered_df2, save_plot, save_path, show_plot=False, cluster1_name='', cluster2_name='', cluster1_iter=0, cluster2_iter=0)¶
Parameters

  • x_df – The x values of the dataset

  • y_df – The y values of the dataset

  • clustered_df1 – The clustered data from the original dataset using the first method

  • clustered_df2 – The clustered data from the original dataset using the second method

  • save_plot – A boolean of whether or not to save the plot

  • save_path – The path to save the plots at

  • show_plot – A boolean of whether or not to show the plot

  • cluster1_name – The name of the first clustering configuration

  • cluster2_name – The name of the second clustering configuration

  • cluster1_iter – The iteration of the first clustering configuration

  • cluster2_iter – The iteration of the second clustering configuration

Returns

Nothing

Plots a visual representation of the rand index metric. It checks for all the locations where two clustering methods gather the same and different cluster values for individual data points, plotting the similarities and differences.

ClusteringComparisonHelper.transform_to_same_range(clustered_df1, clustered_df2)¶
Parameters

  • clustered_df1 – The first DataFrame of clustered data

  • clustered_df2 – The second DataFrame of clustered data

Returns

Two lists of data from the DataFrames that are corrected

Ensures that the min and max values of the two DataFrames are the same. To get to this point, they are already of the same size so we can just apply a transformation which adds a constant equal to the difference in their min values.
